details.description: Bai Hao Yin Zhen, also known as Silver Needle, is a premium white tea known for its delicate, sweet flavor and fine, silvery buds.
details.origin: Grown in the Fujian Province of China, this tea is renowned for its purity and high quality.
details.harvest_notes: Made exclusively from young, unopened tea buds, harvested during the early spring.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Bai Hao Yin Zhen in water heated to 75°C-80°C (167°F-176°F) for 2-3 minutes for a light, sweet infusion.
details.health_benefits: Rich in antioxidants, Silver Needle is believed to support skin health and boost the immune system.
details.popularity: Highly prized among tea enthusiasts for its subtle sweetness and delicate profile.

details.description: Bai Mu Dan, or White Peony, is a popular white tea with a balanced flavor profile of floral sweetness and a hint of earthiness.
details.origin: Originating from Fujian Province, China, Bai Mu Dan is made from young tea leaves and unopened buds.
details.harvest_notes: Harvested in early spring, this tea includes both buds and leaves, giving it a fuller flavor.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Bai Mu Dan in water heated to 75°C-80°C (167°F-176°F) for 2-3 minutes for a smooth, aromatic cup.
details.health_benefits: Known for its high antioxidant content, White Peony may help reduce inflammation and promote relaxation.
details.popularity: Widely enjoyed for its complex flavor and affordability compared to Silver Needle.

details.description: Gong Mei, or Tribute Eyebrow, is a robust white tea with a fruity and slightly woody flavor.
details.origin: Grown in the Fujian and Guangxi regions of China, Gong Mei is one of the more affordable white teas.
details.harvest_notes: Made from more mature leaves, giving it a stronger flavor compared to Bai Hao Yin Zhen or Bai Mu Dan.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Gong Mei in water heated to 80°C-85°C (176°F-185°F) for 2-3 minutes for a fruity, robust infusion.
details.health_benefits: This tea is believed to improve digestion and provide a gentle boost of energy.
details.popularity: Favored for its strong flavor and affordability, Gong Mei is a common choice for everyday white tea drinkers.

details.description: Lao Bai Cha, or Old White Tea, is a uniquely aged white tea with a rich, mellow, and slightly sweet flavor.
details.origin: This tea is aged over several years, often in Fujian, China, to develop its complex flavor.
details.harvest_notes: Made from white tea leaves that are carefully stored and aged to enhance their flavor and aroma.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Lao Bai Cha in water heated to 85°C-90°C (185°F-194°F) for 2-3 minutes to enjoy its rich, matured taste.
details.health_benefits: Believed to improve with age, this tea is often consumed for its calming properties and digestive benefits.
details.popularity: Valued for its unique aging process and smooth, developed flavors.

details.description: Shou Mei is a full-bodied white tea with a bold, earthy flavor and a subtle sweetness.
details.origin: This tea is grown in China’s Fujian and Guangxi regions and made from mature leaves and buds.
details.harvest_notes: Picked later in the season, Shou Mei has a darker color and a stronger flavor due to its mature leaves.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Shou Mei in water heated to 85°C-90°C (185°F-194°F) for 2-3 minutes for a bold, earthy brew.
details.health_benefits: Rich in antioxidants, Shou Mei is said to support digestion and boost overall well-being.
details.popularity: Appreciated for its robust flavor and affordability, making it a popular choice for everyday drinking.

details.description: Ya Bao, or Tea Buds, is a unique white tea made from unopened buds, offering a sweet, pine-like flavor with a hint of spice.
details.origin: Sourced from wild tea trees in Yunnan, China, Ya Bao is a rare and distinctive white tea.
details.harvest_notes: Harvested from wild trees, the buds are minimally processed to preserve their natural sweetness and aroma.
details.brewing_methods: Steep one teaspoon of Ya Bao in water heated to 75°C-80°C (167°F-176°F) for 3-4 minutes for a sweet and spicy infusion.
details.health_benefits: Known for its soothing properties, Ya Bao is often consumed to promote relaxation and mental clarity.
details.popularity: Highly regarded for its unique flavor and rarity, Ya Bao is a favorite among tea connoisseurs.
